The House just voted to terminate President Trump’s #FakeEmergency declaration. The Senate must now join us in rejecting this dangerous & unconstitutional attempt to usurp congressional authority. 

My full statement: https://bit.ly/2tGv2Cd

Thank you to all groups & individuals who testified in front of the Interior-Environment Appropriations subcommittee today. These insights about the priorities of the American public will significantly help us shape our FY2020 Interior and Environment funding bill.

We closed out this afternoon’s hearing with testimony about the importance of stopping wildlife trafficking & supporting the conservation of endangered species and sustainable resource management at home and around the world. Thanks @TheWCS, @action4ifaw & @HSLegFund.

Thanks to @ABCbirds & @sdzglobal for insights on the delicate balance of many bird species and their habitats – birds are the proverbial ‘canary in the coal mine’ for pollution and climate change impacts.

.@protectNPS testimony highlighted NPS' maintenance backlog & staffing/visitor services needs that have gone unaddressed due to budget constraints. National parks preserve our pristine natural places for future generations & need adequate funding to operate safely & sustainably.

The Minnesota Conservation Federation testified for @LWCFCOALITION in support of the Land & Water Conservation Fund. I’m proud to have secured #LWCF dollars for the MN school trust lands in the #BWCA, and I’ll be proud to vote for S. 47 today for permanent #LWCF reauthorization!

Under the Trump administration, a sharp drop in EPA polluter enforcement is leaving communities at risk. In Minnesota, two important cases set up during the last administration should have been completed by now. Instead they’re languishing. http://www.startribune.com/watchdog-group-sees-sharp-drop-in-epa-enforcement-cites-two-minnesota-cases/506356732/ …

Thank you @healthylakes & @ELPCenter for testifying on impacts of climate change on the Great Lakes. The Great Lakes Restoration Initiative is more important than ever as climate change brings new & increased challenges like fish & wildlife habitat loss & more severe algal blooms

Strong EPA funding, especially for environmental justice programs, ensures vital assistance for “those impacted first and worst” by pollution, climate change, and other threats. Our subcommittee is committed to working on cumulative exposure for frontline and legacy communities.

“When you can’t breathe, nothing else matters.” 

Powerful testimony from American @LungAssociation. Every person in every community deserves clean air to breathe -- and the EPA’s enforcement efforts are critical in this endeavor. EPA funding saves lives.

Representatives from Minnesota's @ParkSquare Theatre and @humanities testified about the power of the arts and humanities to celebrate & bring together diverse communities to explore and share their history, culture, & experience.

Christopher Stowe is a retired U.S. Marine and testified today on behalf of the American Art Therapy Association. 

"Art therapy has helped me become a better human, husband, father, and friend. I can also state without a doubt art therapy has helped save my life."

Looking forward to hearing from more than 40 witnesses to gather testimony about America’s urgent needs related to protecting public health, the environment, and our public lands, as well as opportunities to make smart investments in the arts and humanities.

Coming up this morning at 9am ET/8am CT, the Interior-Environment Appropriations Subcommittee holds its first public witness hearing on non-tribal programs. 

The two sessions begin at 9am ( https://youtu.be/uR4Y6ApwV8E  ) & 12:45pm ( https://youtu.be/kzG0YwcGbII  ) pic.twitter.com/wf4k0NIuuW

After hearing from expert witnesses today, I have even more concerns about Acting Sec. Bernhardt’s nomination to lead the DOI. 

I’m requesting an official opinion from the Congressional watchdog agency on the legality of his actions during the #TrumpShutdown.
Because visitor fees were used during the #TrumpShutdown, national parks are going to be waiting even longer for important projects that make our parks safer and more enjoyable for visitors.

The Antideficiency Act exists to protect Congress’ power of the purse. 

The law says an agency may not switch to a different appropriation merely because the one it chose first is now depleted. This is known as the “pick and stick rule.” Pick one and stick to it. pic.twitter.com/y5YI5AvKTm – at Rayburn House Office Building

I have serious questions about Acting Sec. Bernhardt’s decision to use visitor fees to keep some national parks open during the shutdown. These funds are not a slush fund for the Administration to use whenever and however it wants.

Our most fundamental responsibility is to exercise Congress’ power of the purse, as entrusted by the U.S. Constitution. As appropriators, we take this role seriously to ensure taxpayer dollars are handled properly. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o19UKauoqbc …

National park visitor fees are for a very specific use – long-term capital improvement projects. They are not general obligation funds to pay employees or pay for routine maintenance. https://www.wyomingpublicmedia.org/post/democrats-hold-hearing-scrutinizing-funding-national-parks-during-shutdown#stream/0 …
